required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Study of VERU-944 to Ameliorate Hot Flashes in Men With Advanced Prostate Cancer
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo Controlled, Dose Finding Phase 2 Study Comparing Oral Daily Dosing of VERU-944 to Ameliorate the Vasomotor Symptoms Resulting From ADT in Men With Advanced Prostate Cancer

brief_summary.textblock: Randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled, dose finding Phase 2 study comparing oral daily dosing of VERU-944 after a week of loading (daily dosing) with placebo to ameliorate the vasomotor symptoms resulting from androgen deprivation therapy in men with advanced prostate cancer

detailed_description.textblock: This study is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled, dose finding study of VERU-944 to treat hot flashes (vasomotor symptoms) in men with advanced prostate cancer on ADT. The study will have four arms with 30 subjects per arm. The subjects participating in the study will have advanced prostate cancer and will be undergoing androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) with a luteinizing hormone releasing hormone (LHRH) therapy (agonist or antagonist) for at least the three months prior to randomization and be experiencing regular moderate to severe hot flashes while on ADT. Subjects will all continue to receive ADT and will be randomized to receive, for the first four days, a loading dose followed by daily doses of placebo or VERU-944 (10 mg, 50 mg or 100 mg) orally for a total period of 12 weeks.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in frequency of moderate to severe hot flashes at 6 weeks Day 42
primary_outcome.description: Mean change in frequency of moderate to severe hot flashes compared to baseline at 6 weeks

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in severity of moderate to severe hot flashes at 6 Weeks Day 42
secondary_outcome.description: Mean change in severity of moderate to severe hot flashes compared to baseline at 6 weeks

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of frequency of moderate to severe hot flashes at weeks 4,8,10 and 12
secondary_outcome.description: Mean change in frequency of moderate to severe hot flashes compared to baseline at weeks 4,8,10 and 12

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in severity of moderate to severe hot flashes at weeks 4,8.10 and 12
secondary_outcome.description: Mean change in severity of moderate to severe hot flashes compared to baseline at weeks 4,8,10 and12

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in bone turnover markers C-telopeptide (CTX)
secondary_outcome.description: Change in C-telopeptide concentration at day 84 compared to baseline

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in bone turnover markers alkaline phosphatase
secondary_outcome.description: Change in bone specific alkaline phosphatase at day 84 compared to baseline

other_outcome.description: Change in serum PSA concentration comparing baseline to day 30, baseline to day 60 and baseline to day 84 for each treatment group
Change in serum total testosterone concentration comparing baseline to day 30, baseline to day 60 and baseline to day 84 for each treatment group
Change in serum free testosterone concentration comparing baseline to day 30, baseline to day 60 and baseline to day 84 for each treatment group
Change in serum SHBG concentration comparing baseline to day 30, baseline to day 60 and baseline to day 84 for each treatment group

other_outcome.measure: Incidence of Treatment-Emergent Adverse Events (Safety and Tolerability)sess safety
other_outcome.description: Incidence of Treatment-Emergent Adverse Events will be tabulated by MedDRA terms and system organ class. The incidence of AEs and the maximum intensity and frequency of AEs will be summarized. The intensity of AE will be graded according to CTCAE version 4. Changes from baseline will be computed and tested for significant change from baseline to day 114

intervention.description: Treat hot flashes (vasomotor symptoms) in men with advanced prostate cancer on ADT

facility.name: Premier Medical Group of the Hudson Valley
